message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Swarm Robotics: Past, Present, and Future [Point of View]
Paper Abstract: International audience
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.
purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"VEX Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VEX_Robotics"},{"title":"List of robotics companies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_robotics_companies"},{"title":"Laws of robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laws_of_robotics"},{"title":"Soft robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_robotics"},{"title":"Hexapod (robotics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hexapod_(robotics)"},{"title":"Hanson Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanson_Robotics"},{"title":"Horizon Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizon_Robotics"},{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"Robotic arm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_arm"}]

I've completed the web search for "Robotics". Here's a summary of the results:

## Overview of Robotics

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work to create robot systems: Mechanical construction, Electrical components that power and control the machinery, and Software.

## Types and Applications

The search results cover various robotics subfields and applications:

- **Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- **Hexapod Robots**: A hexapod robot is a mechanical vehicle that walks on six legs.

- **Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- **Humanoid Robots**: The results mention companies like Hanson Robotics that develop human-like robots for entertainment and research applications.

The field continues to grow with investment in robotics companies growing due to increasing demand for automation.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "Robotics". Here's a summary of the results:

## Overview of Robotics

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work to create robot systems: Mechanical construction, Electrical components that power and control the machinery, and Software.

## Types and Applications

The search results cover various robotics subfields and applications:

- **Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- **Hexapod Robots**: A hexapod robot is a mechanical vehicle that walks on six legs.

- **Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- **Humanoid Robots**: The results mention companies like Hanson Robotics that develop human-like robots for entertainment and research applications.

The field continues to grow with investment in robotics companies growing due to increasing demand for automation.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Swarm Robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

Here are the search results for **Swarm Robotics**:

## Overview

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.(no content)They take inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

## Key Principles

Swarm robotics principles include that robots are autonomous, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish given tasks.(no content)Robots possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, such as wireless transmission systems, like radio frequency or infrared.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, in which a swarm of up to 20 of robots capable of independently physically connect to each other were used to study swarm behaviors.

## Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely to explore unknown environments.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, for instance mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as 'contribution' or 'survey'. Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence).

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the swarm robotics paper. Here's a summary:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Survey (as indicated by the "[Point of View]" designation and the "Past, Present, and Future" structure)

**Extracted Triples:**

1. **Swarm robotics** (concept)
   - Relation: uses
   - The paper surveys the entire field of swarm robotics across its historical development and future directions

2. **Robotics** (concept)
   - Relation: uses
   - Swarm robotics is a subfield of robotics that the paper contextualizes within the broader discipline

Both triples reference the core topics explicitly mentioned in the paper title, and all validation checks passed successfully. The paper builds on existing work in robotics and swarm robotics, which is appropriate for a survey paper.

Sources:
- [Swarm robotics - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics)
- [Robotics - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics)
